content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct.

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

v.title: Some Microsoft Office apps are losing access to voice tools soon - here's what to know
v.snippet:
Starting January 2026, Microsoft will discontinue voice-related features—such as transcription, dictation, and Read Aloud—in older Office versions that have not been updated to at least version 16.0.18827.20202. This move affects popular applications like Word, Outlook, OneNote, and PowerPoint. Microsoft cites a backend service upgrade as the reason for discontinuing support on older versions, emphasizing improved performance and compatibility with newer systems. Users in Government Cloud environments (GCC, GCC High, and DoD) will receive a two-month extension to implement changes.

Local fallbacks for these voice tools will not be available after the deadline, and those with perpetual licenses may already lack many cloud-based features. In addition to these voice tool changes, Office 2016 and 2019 will reach the end of their extended support by October 14, 2025. Similarly, Office apps on Windows 10 will lose support later in 2025, coinciding with Windows 10's own end-of-life status. These shifts are encouraging broader adoption of Microsoft’s latest software, with Windows 11 surpassing Windows 10 in installations as of July 2025.

entries.title: Everlit tool provides auditory experience for readers
entries.snippet: Hearst has introduced a new audio tool powered by Everlit's advanced text-to-speech technology to enhance content accessibility on myplainview.com and its affiliated publications, including the Plainview Herald, Muleshoe Journal, and Canyon News. Most articles will now be available in audio format, read by a lifelike automated voice. This feature aims to benefit readers who prefer auditory experiences or consume news while multitasking or commuting. The audio player is located in a rectangular box just below the article headline and lead image, with a disclaimer noting the narration is by an AI, not a human. While the system produces near-human speech quality, occasional pronunciation errors may occur. Hearst plans ongoing improvements to the pronunciation library to enhance the experience and invites user feedback at eric.young@hearstnp.com.

entries.title: Microsoft's new AI can turn plain text into a full podcast - and it's freakishly good at it
entries.snippet:
Microsoft has launched a new open-source AI project called **VibeVoice**, a powerful text-to-speech (TTS) framework capable of generating realistic, expressive, long-form audio from plain text — including full-length podcasts. Unlike traditional TTS models, VibeVoice excels in generating up to **90 minutes of audio**, supports **up to four distinct AI-generated speakers**, and handles natural conversation flow and speaker consistency.

Two versions are currently available for testing: a **1.5 billion parameter model**, which supports longer content and a **64k context window**, and a **7 billion parameter model**, offering higher quality but with a **shorter 45-minute audio limit** and **32k context window**. A **lighter 0.5 billion parameter** version for real-time audio is coming soon. The models run on relatively moderate VRAM — from 7GB to 18GB depending on size — making local usage feasible.

VibeVoice supports both **English and Mandarin**, with potential expansion to other languages. It can generate multi-speaker dialogue and express emotions but isn’t yet skilled at singing. Future plans include **voice cloning** capabilities. VibeVoice is accessible via GitHub, Hugging Face, or an online demo, and it promises significant value not just in media but also in accessibility and personal digital assistants.

entries.title: How to use Google Docs' Gemini audio text-to-speech feature
entries.snippet: Google has introduced a new Audio Text-to-Speech feature in Google Docs, powered by its AI tool Gemini. This innovation enables users to listen to their documents being read aloud, rather than just reading them. The feature is designed to enhance accessibility, particularly benefiting users with visual impairments or reading difficulties. It also aids in productivity and proofreading, as hearing content read aloud can help users identify mistakes or absorb information more effectively. Additionally, the audio playback supports various voice styles, allowing users to choose the voice best suited for different tones or types of content. The article outlines steps for setting up and using this feature within Google Docs.

entries.title: LG Adds Cerence AI to Smart TVs
entries.snippet: LG Electronics has integrated Cerence AI’s multi-lingual text-to-speech (TTS) technology into its global lineup of smart TVs, enhancing user experience with natural, voice-powered interactions. The collaboration brings cloud-based and edge TTS capabilities to LG’s webOS platform, supporting 65 voices and languages for intuitive and accessible communication. This AI advancement allows TVs to respond conversationally to user commands, such as finding movies or making recommendations, improving ease of use and accessibility for all users, including the visually impaired. The integration meets growing global accessibility requirements, including those set by the European Accessibility Act. The TTS upgrade delivers responsive performance with minimal latency and hardware impact, helping manage costs. LG and Cerence plan to expand this technology across additional webOS-based products in the future.
